content:
Sure, here's an example of how two players could both flop quads in Texas Hold'em:

Player 1: AhAc (pocket aces)
Player 2: ThTs (pocket tens)
Flop: AcTsTs (ace of clubs, ten of spades, ten of hearts)

In this example, both players have been dealt a pocket pair, and the flop contains two of the remaining aces and two of the remaining tens. This means that both players have flopped quads, with player 1 having four aces (including the ace of hearts in their hand) and player 2 having four tens (including the ten of spades in their hand).

As mentioned earlier, the probability of both players flopping quads is incredibly low, but it is still technically possible.
